questions.text: The mitochondrial sheaths are found in which part of sperm?
questions.solution:
The structure of sperm is as follow:


Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Tail

  • The tail of the sperm refers to the entire flagellum, which includes the middle piece, principal piece, and end piece. However, mitochondria are only found in the middle piece.

Choice C: Principal Piece

  • The principal piece is the longest part of the sperm tail, providing structural support and flexibility but does not contain mitochondria.

Choice D: Connecting Piece

  • The connecting piece is located between the head and tail, helping anchor the tail to the nucleus, but it does not contain mitochondria.

Key Takeaway:

Mitochondrial sheaths are found in the middle piece of the sperm, where they generate ATP for motility.

questions.text: In which stage of meiosis is the primary oocyte arrested?
questions.solution:
• oogenesis at different phases of life is as follow:

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Leptotene

  • The leptotene stage is the first phase of prophase I, where chromosomes begin to condense. The arrest does not happen here.

Choice C: Zygotene

  • The zygotene stage is when homologous chromosomes start pairing (synapsis). Arrest does not occur at this stage.

Choice D: Pachytene

  • The pachytene stage is where crossing-over occurs, but primary oocytes do not remain arrested here.

Key Takeaway:

Primary oocytes are arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I until puberty, when they resume meiosis I before ovulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is first formed by the migration of epiblast along with the primitive streak?
questions.solution:
• The cells of embryoblast differentiate and arrange themselves into two layers
    1. A superficial layer of columnar cells - Epiblast
    2. A deep layer of flattened cells - Hypoblast
  • The flask shaped cells of epiblast through primitive streak move inward and replace the hypoblast cells to form the endoderm.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Cardiac Mesoderm

  • The cardiac mesoderm arises later from the mesodermal cells that migrate through the primitive streak and position themselves in the cranial region of the embryo.

Choice C: Epidermis

  • The epidermis arises from the ectoderm, which is not the first to form during gastrulation.

Choice D: Neural Groove

  • The neural groove forms later from the ectoderm, specifically the neural plate, during neurulation, which occurs after gastrulation.

Key Takeaway:

The endoderm is the first germ layer to form from the migration of epiblast cells through the primitive streak, replacing the hypoblast.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a derivative of the neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Retinal pigment epithelium is derived from neural ectoderm.

Derivatives of Neural crest cells are as follow:

  • Pseudo unipolar neuron of dorsal root ganglia
  • Neuron of sensory ganglia of cranial nerves
  • Cells of autonomic ganglia
  • Satellite cells of all sensory ganglia
  • Schwann cell
  • Melanocyte
  • Chromaffin cells of suprarenal medulla
  • Pia and arachnoid mater
  • Odontoblasts and dentine
  • Choroid, Sclera, Corneal epithelium

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Ciliary Muscles

  • Ciliary muscles develop from neural crest cells, which contribute to the mesenchymal tissues forming the intraocular muscles.

Choice C: Ciliary Ganglion

  • Ciliary ganglion (a parasympathetic ganglion associated with the oculomotor nerve) is a derivative of neural crest cells, as all autonomic ganglia originate from the neural crest.

Choice D: Melanocytes

  • Melanocytes, which produce melanin in the skin and other tissues, are direct derivatives of neural crest cells.

Key Takeaway:

Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is derived from neural ectoderm, whereas ciliary muscles, ciliary ganglion, and melanocytes are neural crest derivatives.

questions.text: Which mechanism is responsible for release of secretion for the marked gland?
questions.solution:
The marked gland is sebaceous gland.

Exocrine glands secrete their products by three different methods.


Key Takeaway:

Sebaceous glands use the holocrine mechanism, where the entire cell disintegrates to release its secretion (sebum).

Reference: https://www.dreamstime.com/sebaceous-gland-formed-multiple-acinar-glands-which-surrounds-hair-follicle-holocrine-whose-cells-accumulate-sebum-image231201613

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Primitive streak:

  • It is a linear thickened band of ectodermal cells at the caudal end of the embryo in the midline.
  • It is formed due to proliferation and migration of cells of ectoderm on the superior surface of embryonic disc in the midline.
  • It becomes visible on the dorsal surface of embryonic disc on day 15 of embryonic development as a narrow groove flanked by a slight bulge on either side.
  • Functions:
    1. It gives rise to intraembryonic mesoderm, septum transversum and notochord.
    2. Determines the future craniocaudal axis of embryo.
    3. Demarcates the embryo into left and right halves.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Notochord

  • The notochord is a rod-like structure derived from the primitive node and mesoderm.
  • It serves as the primary axial support and plays a crucial role in the induction of the neural plate.

Choice C: Neural Groove

  • The neural groove forms later in development from the neural plate, which results from the notochord's signaling.
  • It eventually folds to create the neural tube, which forms the central nervous system.

Choice D: Secondary Neural Plate

  • The secondary neural plate refers to structures involved in neural tube formation during secondary neurulation, primarily in the caudal region.
  • It is not directly related to the primitive streak.

Key Takeaway:

The primitive streak is the first visible structure that initiates gastrulation, helping to define the body's midline and symmetry, and plays a vital role in the formation of mesoderm and notochord.

Reference: https://www.vcbio.science.ru.nl/en/virtuallessons/embryology/chicken-33-36h/

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
The given image is of microscopic structure of cardiac muscle. The marked structure is intercalated disc.

Cardiac Muscle:

  • It is made up of elongated fibres containing myofibrils.
  • Myofibrils show transverse striations.
  • The fibres of the cardiac muscle branch and anastomose with each other to form network.
  • Each fibre (myocyte) has its own centrally placed elongated nuclei.
  • The junctions between adjoining cardiac myocytes are seen as intercalated discs.
  • Intercalated discs are formed by cell membranes of adjacent myocytes and by a layer of dense cytoplasm present next to the cell membrane.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Connective Tissue

  • Connective tissue is found surrounding muscle fibers but does not form the distinct dark-stained junctional structures seen in intercalated discs.

Choice C: Cytoskeletal Condensation

  • Cytoskeletal condensations refer to actin, myosin, and other structural proteins inside the muscle cell but do not form visible, dark-stained bands like intercalated discs.

Choice D: Nerve Fiber

  • Nerve fibers innervate cardiac muscle but do not appear as thickened, dark-staining junctions like intercalated discs.

Key Takeaway:

Intercalated discs are essential structures in cardiac muscle, providing mechanical strength and electrical coupling, allowing the heart to function as a syncytium.

Reference: https://ohiostate.pressbooks.pub/vethisto/chapter/4-cardiac-muscle/

questions.text: Identify the structure on prostate biopsy:
questions.solution:
The given image is a microscopic image of Prostate gland.

  • Prostate Gland:
    • Fibromuscular type of glands.
    • Parenchyma: made up of alveoli. Epithelium lining is secretory in nature.
    • Stroma: Contains smooth muscle fibres mixed with connective tissue, blood vessels, lymphatic and nerves.
  • Corpora amylacea:
    • Prostatic concretions seen in old people.
    • Oval dense bodies of glycoproteins in the lumen of gland alveoli.
    • Due to condensation of secretory products, which may become calcified.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Psammoma Bodies

  • Psammoma bodies are concentrically laminated, calcified structures found in certain tumors (e.g., papillary thyroid carcinoma, serous ovarian carcinoma, meningiomas).
  • Unlike corpora amylacea, they are more regular and laminated in structure.

Choice C: Lewy Body

  • Lewy bodies are intracellular eosinophilic inclusions found in neurons, associated with Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia.
  • They contain α-synuclein and are not seen in the prostate.

Choice D: Corpora Arenacea (Brain Sand)

  • Corpora arenacea are calcium deposits in the pineal gland, also called brain sand.
  • Found in older individuals, they are not present in the prostate.

Key Takeaway:

Corpora amylacea are prostatic concretions that appear in aging men and can be seen in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corpora_amylacea

questions.text: The marked structure serves as the surface landmark for which anatomical structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is pterion.

  • Pterion:
  • The anterior part of the floor of temporal fossa is crossed by an H shaped suture where four bones-frontal, parietal, greater wing of sphenoid and temporal adjoin each other.
  • It lies 4 cm above the midpoint of the zygomatic arch and 2.5 cm behind the frontozygomatic suture.
  • Deep to the Pterion lie, the middle meningeal vein, the anterior division of the middle meningeal artery, and the stem of the lateral sulcus of the brain (Sylvian point).

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Pineal Gland

  • The pineal gland is located deep in the brain, between the superior colliculi of the midbrain.
  • It is not related to the pterion.

Choice B: Wernicke's Area

  • Wernicke's area (responsible for language comprehension) is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere, posterior to the lateral sulcus.
  • It is not directly beneath the pterion.

Choice D: Internal Carotid Artery Siphon

  • The internal carotid artery siphon refers to the S-shaped curve of the internal carotid artery as it travels through the cavernous sinus and into the cranial cavity.
  • It is not located beneath the pterion.

Key Takeaway:

The pterion serves as an important surface landmark for the stem of the lateral sulcus (Sylvian fissure) and is clinically significant due to its proximity to the middle meningeal artery, making it a common site for epidural hematomas.

Reference: https://anatomyzone.com/articles/pterion/

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
The given image is an angiogram of the external carotid artery. The marked structure is Superficial temporal artery.

External carotid artery:

  • External carotid artery is one of the terminal branches of the common carotid artery.
  • It begins in the carotid triangle at the level of the upper border of thyroid cartilage.
  • It runs upwards and backwards and laterally and terminates behind the neck of the mandible by dividing into maxillary and superficial temporal artery.
  • Branches:
    • Anterior: Superior thyroid artery, lingual artery, Facial artery
    • Posterior: occipital artery, Posterior auricular artery
    • Medial: Ascending pharyngeal artery
    • Terminal: Maxillary artery and Superficial temporal artery.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Posterior Auricular Artery

  • The posterior auricular artery is a posterior branch of the external carotid artery, supplying the auricle and scalp behind the ear.
  • It is not a terminal branch and is less prominent on angiograms compared to the superficial temporal artery.

Choice C: Middle Meningeal Artery

  • The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery, not the external carotid artery directly.
  • It enters the skull via the foramen spinosum and supplies the dura mater and cranial bones.
  • Since the given image is an external carotid angiogram, the middle meningeal artery would not be the marked structure.

Choice D: Occipital Artery

  • The occipital artery is another posterior branch of the external carotid artery, supplying the posterior scalpand upper back of the neck.
  • It does not ascend over the zygomatic arch, unlike the superficial temporal artery.

Key Takeaway:

The superficial temporal artery, a terminal branch of the external carotid artery, is marked on the angiogram and is palpable over the zygomatic arch, making it clinically relevant for diagnosing temporal arteritis (Giant Cell Arteritis).

questions.text: The posterior end of the marked structure is present at the level of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is inferior concha. The posterior end of inferior concha is present at level of Eustachian tube opening.

Eustachian Tube:

  • It is also known as Auditory tube and Pharyngotympanic tube.
  • It is a trumpet shaped channel which connects the middle ear cavity with the nasopharynx.
  • It is about 4 cm long and is directed downwards, forwards and medially.
  • It is divided into bony and cartilaginous parts.
  • The bony part forms posterior and lateral one third of the tube and cartilaginous part forms the anterior and medial two third of the tube.
  • The tube provides a communication of the middle ear cavity with the exterior ,thus ensuring equal air pressure on the both sides of the tympanic

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Sphenopalatine Foramen

  • The sphenopalatine foramen is located higher up in the lateral wall of the nasal cavity, near the middle meatus.
  • It is the opening through which the sphenopalatine artery (a branch of the maxillary artery) enters the nasal cavity.
  • It is not related to the posterior end of the inferior concha.

Choice C: Odontoid Process

  • The odontoid process (dens) is a bony projection of the axis (C2 vertebra).
  • It is located in the upper cervical spine and is not associated with the nasal cavity or conchae.

Choice D: Sphenoidal Sinus

  • The sphenoidal sinus is located posterior and superior to the nasal cavity, in the body of the sphenoid bone.
  • Its opening is near the superior nasal meatus, not near the inferior concha.

Key Takeaway:

The posterior end of the inferior concha is located at the level of the Eustachian tube opening, which connects the nasopharynx to the middle ear. This anatomical relationship is important for middle ear ventilation and pressure regulation.

Reference: https://www.getbodysmart.com/nasal-cavity/respiratory-mucosa-anatomy/

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
The marked structure is oculomotor nerve.

  • Oculomotor Nerve:
    • It arises from the medial aspect of the cerebral peduncle.
    • It pierces pia and arachnoid mater and enters the cavernous sinus.
    • It lies above the trochlear nerve in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus.
    • It divides into upper and lower divisions and enters into orbit through superior orbital fissure.
    • It supplies Superior, Inferior and medial rectus and Inferior oblique muscles of the eyeball.
    • It also supplies levator palpebrae superioris, Constrictor and dilator pupillae and ciliary muscle.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Abducens Nerve

  • The abducens nerve (CN VI) arises from the pons, near the midline, and has a more medial course than the oculomotor nerve.
  • It passes through the cavernous sinus, but it is not located in the lateral wall—instead, it runs inside the sinus adjacent to the internal carotid artery.
  • It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure and innervates only the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

Choice C: Trochlear Nerve

  • The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is the smallest cranial nerve and has a dorsal origin from the midbrain, making it unique among cranial nerves.
  • It runs along the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus, below the oculomotor nerve.
  • It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure and innervates only the superior oblique muscle.

Choice D: Ophthalmic Division (V1) of Trigeminal Nerve

  • The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) provides sensory innervation to the forehead, cornea, and upper eyelid.
  • It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure, dividing into the frontal, lacrimal, and nasociliary branches.
  • It does not supply any extraocular muscles, distinguishing it from the oculomotor nerve.

Key Takeaway:

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is responsible for most eye movements, eyelid elevation, and pupil constriction. It runs in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus, passes through the superior orbital fissure, and supplies several extraocular muscles.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male recovering from facial nerve palsy complains of food getting stuck between the cheek and the teeth while eating. What is the muscle affected in this case?
questions.solution:
The patient has facial nerve palsy. Following are muscles supplied by facial nerve and their actions are as follow:

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Orbicularis Oris

  • This muscle encircles the mouth and is responsible for puckering the lips (lip closure).
  • Damage would result in difficulty with pursing the lips, but not food entrapment between the cheek and teeth.

Choice B: Zygomaticus Major

  • This muscle elevates the corner of the mouth, contributing to smiling.
  • Facial nerve palsy affecting this muscle causes asymmetrical smiling, but does not lead to difficulty in chewing.

Choice D: Levator Labii Superioris

  • This muscle elevates the upper lip, playing a role in facial expressions.
  • Dysfunction would cause difficulty raising the upper lip, but not food accumulation in the oral vestibule.

Key Takeaway:

The buccinator muscle (Choice C) is responsible for keeping food between the teeth during mastication. Dysfunction due to facial nerve palsy leads to food getting trapped between the cheek and teeth, making chewing difficult.

questions.text: Injury of posterior interosseous nerve leads to:
questions.solution:
The posterior interosseous nerve is a deep branch of radial nerve at the lateral part of cubital fossa. It supplies all extensor muscles of the forearm except Brachioradialis, Extensor carpi radialis longus and anconeus.

Injury of radial nerve at elbow: Radial tunnel syndrome:

  • It is an entrapment neuropathy of the deep branch of the radial nerve at the elbow.
  • Loss of extension of the wrist and fingers but no wrist drop.
  • Pain over the extensor aspect of the forearm.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Loss of extension of the wrist

  • Incorrect because wrist extension is maintained by the extensor carpi radialis longus (ECRL), which is supplied by the radial nerve before it gives off the PIN.
  • Only finger extension is lost, not wrist extension.

Choice C: Loss of supination

  • The supinator muscle is partially innervated by the PIN, but supination is also performed by the biceps brachii (musculocutaneous nerve).
  • Even if the PIN is damaged, supination remains intact due to biceps brachii function.

Choice D: Wrist drop

  • Wrist drop occurs with a high radial nerve injury (proximal to elbow), not a PIN lesion.
  • Since ECRL is spared, wrist extension remains partially intact, preventing wrist drop.

Key Takeaway:

The posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) injury leads to loss of extension of the digits (Choice A), but wrist extension remains intact due to ECRL function, preventing wrist drop.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy underwent a splenectomy for thrombocytopenic purpura. During the procedure, the surgeon noticed bleeding while separating the spleen from the stomach. Which vessel is most likely implicated in this bleeding?
questions.solution:
The short gastric vessels are present within gastrosplenic ligament so most likely injured during separation of spleen from the stomach.

Ligaments of Spleen:

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Right gastroepiploic artery

  • This artery arises from the gastroduodenal artery and runs along the greater curvature of the stomach within the gastrocolic ligament, not the gastrosplenic ligament.
  • It is not directly involved in splenic mobilization.

Choice C: Left gastroepiploic artery

  • The left gastroepiploic artery is a branch of the splenic artery and runs along the greater curvature of the stomach.
  • Though it is near the spleen, it is not typically the main vessel injured during splenic separation from the stomach, as it is located in the gastrocolic ligament, not the gastrosplenic ligament.

Choice D: Splenic vessels

  • The splenic artery and vein are located in the lienorenal (splenorenal) ligament, not the gastrosplenic ligament.
  • While splenic vessels may be ligated during a splenectomy, they are not the most likely cause of bleeding when separating the spleen from the stomach.

Key Takeaway:

During splenectomy, bleeding at the gastrosplenic ligament is most likely due to injury of the short gastric arteries (Choice B), as they run through this ligament and connect the spleen to the stomach.

questions.text: During walking the hip bone on the side of the suspended leg is raised by the action of which muscle present in the supporting leg?
questions.solution:
The Gluteus medius muscle is abductor of hip joint.

  • When the body weight is supported on one limb, the gluteus medius and minimus of the supported side raise the opposite and unsupported side of the pelvis.
  • However, if the abductor mechanism is defective, the unsupported side of the pelvis drops and this is known as a positive Trendelenburg's sign.
  • The sign is positive in defects of power i.e. paralysis of glutei medius and minimus; defect of fulcrum, i.e. congenital or pathological dislocation of the hip and defect of the weight, i.e. ununited fracture of the neck of the femur.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Gluteus maximus

  • The gluteus maximus is not a primary abductor but instead functions mainly as a hip extensor.
  • It is responsible for hip extension and external rotation, particularly during rising from a seated position or climbing stairs.
  • It does not play a significant role in lifting the unsupported side of the pelvis during walking.

Choice C: Obturator internus

  • Obturator internus is a deep hip muscle that functions as a lateral rotator of the hip, not an abductor.
  • It does not contribute to stabilizing the pelvis or lifting the unsupported leg.

Choice D: Quadratus lumborum

  • Quadratus lumborum (QL) is a core muscle located in the lower back.
  • It plays a role in lateral flexion of the trunk and stabilizing the spine, but it does not abduct the hip or lift the pelvis during walking.

Key Takeaway:

The gluteus medius (Choice A), along with gluteus minimus, stabilizes the pelvis during walking by preventing it from sagging on the unsupported side. Weakness in these muscles results in Trendelenburg's sign, where the pelvis drops instead of staying level.
